docs.lead_paragraph: A small suburban Philadelphia college apologized Friday after it stirred controversy with an email advertising a fitness program to overweight students.

headline.main: Fitness Email Stirs Controversy at Pennsylvania College
headline.print_headline: Fitness Email Stirs Controversy at Pennsylvania College

docs.snippet: A small suburban Philadelphia college apologized Friday after it stirred controversy with an email advertising a fitness program to overweight students.

docs.lead_paragraph: Embattled milk producers launched a social media campaign this week to rebuild public confidence in the health benefits of their product.

headline.main: Milk Does a Body Good? A Look at the Science
headline.print_headline: Milk Does a Body Good? A Look at the Science

docs.snippet: Embattled milk producers launched a social media campaign this week to rebuild public confidence in the health benefits of their product.

headline.main: Are Vitamin Drinks a Bad Idea?

docs.abstract: Some nutrition scientists are concerned that with the profusion of fortified foods, beverages and supplements, many people may be ingesting levels of vitamins and other nutrients that are not only unnecessary, but potentially harmful.
docs.snippet: Some nutrition scientists are concerned that with the profusion of fortified foods, beverages and supplements, many people may be ingesting levels of vitamins and other nutrients that are not only unnecessary, but potentially harmful.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen turtles that were stranded by cold weather last year in Massachusetts have successfully undergone rehab and have been returned to waters off Louisiana's coast.

headline.main: Cold-Stunned Turtles Rehabilitated in New Orleans, Released
headline.print_headline: Cold-Stunned Turtles Rehabilitated in New Orleans, Released

docs.snippet: Nearly two dozen turtles that were stranded by cold weather last year in Massachusetts have successfully undergone rehab and have been returned to waters off Louisiana's coast.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sandra G. Hassink, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, responds to an online column by Charles M. Blow.
docs.snippet: Sandra G. Hassink, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, responds to an online column by Charles M. Blow.

docs.lead_paragraph: Expo 2015 officials have heightened security measures surrounding the world's fair in Milan, which is expected to attract more than 20 million visitors over six months, following the terror attacks in Paris, the event's commissioner said Thursday.

headline.main: Milan Expo 2015 Tightening Security After Paris Attacks
headline.print_headline: Milan Expo 2015 Tightening Security After Paris Attacks

docs.snippet: Expo 2015 officials have heightened security measures surrounding the world's fair in Milan, which is expected to attract more than 20 million visitors over six months, following the terror attacks in Paris, the event's commissioner said Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hershey has a sudden hankering for protein, with plans to add jerky to its lineup.

headline.main: Hershey Dips Into Meat Market With Krave Jerky
headline.print_headline: Hershey Dips Into Meat Market With Krave Jerky

docs.snippet: Hershey has a sudden hankering for protein, with plans to add jerky to its lineup.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.N. Children's Fund launched a record $3.1 billion appeal on Thursday to enable it to help children caught up in a "new generation" of conflicts and disasters round the world, $1 billion more than it sought in 2014.

headline.main: UNICEF Makes Record Appeal to Help 60 Million Children in Crisis
headline.print_headline: UNICEF Makes Record Appeal to Help 60 Million Children in Crisis

docs.snippet: The U.N. Children's Fund launched a record $3.1 billion appeal on Thursday to enable it to help children caught up in a "new generation" of conflicts and disasters round the world, $1 billion more than it sought in 2014.
